summary: This document is an email chain from October 2020 between FBI personnel and attorney Gloria Allred, discussing logistical arrangements for Epstein victims to attend a DOJ briefing in Miami on November 12, 2020. The primary concerns are COVID-19 travel restrictions and requests for remote participation options like secure video links.

persons.name: Gloria Allred
persons.context: She is the primary correspondent, advocating for her clients (Epstein victims) to have remote participation options for a DOJ briefing due to COVID-19 travel concerns and logistical hurdles.

persons.name: Mariann Wang
persons.context: She is copied on emails and is asked by Allred to provide the locations of their clients to the FBI.

persons.name: Diane Aldrich
persons.context: She is contacted by the FBI to confirm receipt of meeting invites for Allred's clients and promises to follow up.

persons.name: Jon Huber
persons.context: Mentioned in an excerpted email from an unnamed individual as a capable U.S. Attorney who could potentially help facilitate logistical arrangements for remote participation.

connections.description: Allred identifies Wang as her co-counsel and includes her on correspondence with the FBI regarding client logistics.
Diane Aldrich is identified as the Executive Assistant to Gloria Allred, handling administrative communications.
An unnamed email writer states they know Jon Huber and believe he would help facilitate arrangements, suggesting Allred's firm or her clients have a connection to his office.

events.title: DOJ Briefing for Epstein Victims in Miami
events.description: A meeting scheduled by the Department of Justice in Miami to provide information to victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The email chain discusses logistics, including time (9am-12pm EST), travel concerns due to COVID-19, and requests for remote participation options.

locations: Los Angeles, California (6300 Wilshire Blvd., Suite 1500)
keyFacts: The DOJ scheduled a victim briefing in Miami for November 12, 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Attorney Gloria Allred strongly advocated for remote participation options (secure phone line, Zoom) for her Epstein victim clients, citing health risks and unreasonable travel demands.
Allred's clients were located internationally and across the U.S., including in Western states, making in-person attendance in Miami difficult.
The FBI and DOJ were actively discussing alternative options for the meeting, such as having victims view from local FBI offices.
The email chain reveals logistical tensions between victim accessibility and the government's planned format for disseminating case information.
